primary_factors: No accumulating snow or active precipitation expected for Monday morning in Rockford (0" forecast in provided hourly data)
Wind chills ~6–10°F during bus window: cold/uncomfortable but far above Michigan extreme-cold closure thresholds (-15°F to -20°F / ≤-20°F)
Main plausible disruption mechanism is *carryover/refreeze black ice* on bridges, shaded backroads, residential streets, and parking lots (temps stay below freezing all day)
Infrastructure/operations signal: primary roads/highways expected clear; any treatment would be spot-salting rather than plow response
News/community signal: no official Rockford or neighboring-district closure postings found; no closure cascade or strong community buzz
decision_rationale: All specialists converge on a cold-but-quiet Monday with no new snow/ice falling during the critical 6–9 AM window. That strongly suppresses full-closure odds in snow-hardened West Michigan. The only meaningful ‘gotcha’ is residual moisture from the weekend refreezing into patchy black ice—especially on secondary roads, bridges, and in parking lots/sidewalks—more consistent with localized hazards and possibly a *delay* decision than a district-wide closure. News intel found no Rockford or nearby district closure announcements and no domino-effect cascade. Power-grid data could not be live-verified (interactive maps), but there is no weather pattern Monday (no ice, no high wind) that typically generates new widespread outages; outage-driven closure risk remains low unless there are ongoing pockets from the weekend. Web verification does not show any ≤-20°F wind chill trigger, and the Weather.com data appeared stale/misaligned; importantly, neither web nor API indicates extreme-cold thresholds. Net: schools should be OPEN; keep a small non-zero closure probability for the black-ice wildcard if Sunday night ends wetter than expected or if early crash/slide reports spike.

collaboration.summary: Agents reached consensus after 1 round(s) with 2.0% spread. Average probability: 5%.
